p: Curzerene was widely found in “Equador” (23.21 ± 4.96%) and “Guajarina” (23.39 ± 4.45%) cultivars, and is considered a derivative of furanodiene, which is produced from a reversible thermal rearrangement known as the Cope rearrangement [ 66]. It is a type of reaction characterized by the substitution of alkenes when the compound is found at high temperatures [ 67], which suggests that curzerene may have been produced during the essential oil extraction as well as during the gas chromatographic analysis [ 68].
